instruction:
Business Correspondence

This section of the test contains multiple-choice questions, which you must answer by using your computer mouse to select the correct response. Upon answering a question, you can go to the next question by clicking the Next button on the Menu bar.

During this section of the test, if you choose you may skip an item and then later return to that item.

When you are finished, select Done from the Menu bar. Your Test Administrator may have set a time limit for this test section. If there is a time limit, you will be told how much time you have. If a time limit has been set for this section of the test, you will notice a countdown timer on the Status bar in the lower right corner of the screen, showing the amount of time remaining to complete this section of the test.

questions.questionText: Which of the following sections of a business correspondence letter appears first?
What is the purpose of a preface in a report?

options.text: To serve as a title page for the report.
To save the reader time by presenting conclusions about the report.
To indicate for whom the report is written or the purpose of the report.
To display the pertinent data/or and evidence in the report.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of the appendices section of a report?

options.text: To offer advice unsubstantiated by evidence.
To provide an organized section for reference data.
To review data that may have been missed during the primary analysis.

questions.questionText: What does the inside address refer to in a business correspondence letter?
Which part of a business correspondence letter contains a brief phrase explaining the content or purpose of the letter?
What is the complimentary closing of a business correspondence letter?

options.text: A small closing paragraph designed to courteously end an inquiry letter.
A brief message between colleagues in a related field.
An indication that the letter contains no further substantive text.
A word or phrase used to end the message.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of an executive summary?

options.text: To briefly mention all of the C-level executives involved in the creation of the report.
To offer the executive for whom the report was created an opportunity to explain why the report was created.
To provide the reader with a brief overview of the report's most important findings.
To summarize the stance of executive management regarding the topic of the report.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an appropriate font choice for a formal business correspondence letter?
What does the term "In Care of" mean when used on a business correspondence letter's address?

options.text: The letter was intended for an organization instead of an individual.
The letter is meant to be delivered by hand.
The letter must be delivered to its intended recipient by a third party.
The letter does not need to be routed.

questions.questionText: What does "Encl" at the bottom of a business correspondence letter indicate?

options.text: There is more than one page to the letter.
Another item is included with the letter.
This letter will be followed by more letters in the future.
There will be documents that will be sent in another letter.

questions.questionText: Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: A package was received by John Doe, 321 N. Vine Street, Springfield IL, 62777
A package was received by John Doe 321 N. Vine Street, Springfield, IL, 62777
A package was received by John Doe, 321 N. Vine Street, Springfield, IL 62777
A package was received by John Doe 321 N. Vine Street, Springfield, IL, 62777

questions.questionText: What is the appropriate salutation for a business correspondence letter?
What is the appropriate way to express the date on the top of the page on a business correspondence letter?
Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: Three crates contain thirty-two books each, while the other contains 2.
Three crates contain thirty-two books each, while the other contains two.
Three crates contain 32 books each, while the other contains 2.
Three crates contain 32 books each, while the other contains two.

questions.questionText: Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: Three crates contain thirty-two books each, while the other contains 2.
Three crates contain thirty-two books each, while the other contains two.
Three crates contain 32 books each, while the other contains 2.
Three crates contain 32 books each, while the other contains two.

questions.questionText: Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: The company has offices in three states: California, New York, and Florida
The company has offices in three states: California; New York; and Florida
The company has offices in three states, California, New York, and Florida
The company has offices in three states; California, New York, and Florida

questions.questionText: How many inches is the typical indent for the body paragraphs in a standard block format business correspondence letter?
What is the correct line spacing between different sections of a business correspondence letter?
Which of the following components of a business correspondence letter is between the complimentary closing and the author's typed name?
According to the U.S. Postal Service, which of the following is the correct way of including a U.S. "zip plus four" zip code in the mailing address on an envelope?
What type of margins are appropriate for business correspondence letters?
Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: Sally has started a new job tomorrow.
Sally starts a new job tomorrow.
Sally started a new job tomorrow.
Sally start a new job tomorrow.

questions.questionText: Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: The student left the school with never scarcely a protest.
The student left the school without scarcely a protest.
The boy hardly scarcely protested with leaving the school.
The student left the school with scarcely a protest.

questions.questionText: Choose the most appropriately written sentence for a business correspondence letter.

options.text: John and I are going to the meeting.
John and me are going to the meeting.
John and myself are going to the meeting.
Me and John are going to the meeting.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. Throughout (1) the text the aim has been to go directly to the (2) heart of the problem under consideration.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. Instead, (1) an effot has been made to outline, first the essential nature of the problem, and second, ( 2) the fundamental principles which affect its solution.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. It goes without saying that the (1) success of this book depend largely (2) upon the use which the teacher makes of it.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. The (1) text covers the fundamentals of three distinct (2) fields - economics, sociology, and government.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. Part two (1) might, serve as a base to build up a special course in economics, while part three would serve as (2) a basis for a similar course in another subject.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. (1) Though the text is the result of the cooperative efforts of a considerable number of (2) specialists, its treatment of the problems of American life is neither dogmatic nor arbitrary.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. The (1) effort has being to treat all of our problems sanely and hopefully, but also make it clear (2) that many of these questions are still unsettling.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. (1) This fact has strongly influenced the manner in (2) which the problems have been treated.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. It is not too much to say (1) that the Profession of Baking is (2) probably in trouble.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the answer that correctly identifies both the region of the sentence containing the error, and the specific nature of the error. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. There (1) are many benefits to hiking, including (2) relaxation exercise and getting out into nature.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. The student of this text (A) begins, not with the mechanism of (B) government, but with the historical background of (C) American democracy, its origin, development, and promise for the future.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. There is an increasing demand (A) for a Textbook that will bring the student into direct contact with the current issues of (B) American life, and which will provide practical training to those who soon must grapple with the (C) economic, social, and political problems of our own time.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. This is a (A) brief survey of the economic life of the (B) nation, because economic life (C) constitute the fundamental basis of our problems.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. (A) That is what (B) happened in the (C) building, last night.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. (A)The student will soon be (B) confronted, with such puzzling matters as (C) socialism, the control of immigration, and taxation reform.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. The current (A) problems are difficult, but now all of (B) them were also of (C) vital importance.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. In dealing with (A) these issues, the attempt has been made to keep in (B) mind the students can-not prepare; on the other hand, the civic demands which the future (C) will make upon him have not been ignored.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. The textbook is very poorly written. Starting from (A) social problems, the text skips to the (B) economic and social functions of (C) governme nt; and then to the question of making government effective.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. It has not been (A) easy compressed into a single (B) volume the most important of our national problems. (C) Obviously, a rigid selection has been necessary.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. If (A) the school does not prepare him to grapple (B) with these questions intelligently, he can (C) only partially fulfill the obligations of citizenship.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: Select the underlined area in the sentence where there is an error in grammar, punctuation, or spelling. Note that the underline itself is not actually part of the sentence and should not be considered an error. Congress (A) has that power: but if a (B) foreign nation invades our country, the (C) President uses the Army and Navy to defend the country.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: The following sentence may contain an error. Select the correct type of error if one is present. This book is designed to give the farmer a practical working knowledge of Electricity.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: The following sentence may contain an error. Select the correct type of error if one is present. We should consider things that happened in the passed to help us make decisions.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: The following sentence may contain an error. Select the correct type of error if one is present. Forest fires, which can cause significant property damage must be dealt with quickly.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: The following sentence may contain an error. Select the correct type of error if one is present. Paralegals assist attorneys in doing research; and drafting important legal documents.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.

questions.questionText: The following sentence may contain an error. Select the correct type of error if one is present. We have departed from the Jeffersonian view and we now think that the government can do a great many things helpfully, provided it has experts to do them.

options.text: The sentence is correct as is.
